chapters.title: The Wonderful World of Science
topics: Meaning and scope of science in everyday life
Observation, curiosity and asking questions
Simple activities that show scientific thinking
Role of scientists and inventions in improving life
Safety and ethics in doing experiments

notes.summary: This chapter introduces science as a way to understand the world through observation, questioning, and simple activities connected to daily life.
key_points: Science is a systematic way of studying natural phenomena using observations and experiments.
Curiosity, asking good questions, and careful note‑making are the starting points of scientific learning.
Many tools and technologies used in homes, schools, and farms are results of scientific work.
Following safety rules and handling materials carefully are essential while doing science activities.

chapters.title: Diversity in the Living World
topics: Living and non‑living things: basic differences
Classification based on visible features (plants, animals, micro‑organisms)
Habitats: terrestrial and aquatic environments
Adaptations of organisms to their surroundings (examples)
Importance of biodiversity and need to protect it

notes.summary: The chapter explains how living things differ from non‑living things and how the huge variety of organisms can be grouped based on features and habitats.
key_points: Living things grow, respire, move on their own, respond to stimuli, reproduce, and need food whereas non‑living things do not show all these characteristics.
Organisms can be broadly grouped as plants, animals, and micro‑organisms based on structure and mode of nutrition.
Habitats such as forests, deserts, mountains, ponds, and seas influence body features and behavior of organisms.
Adaptations like thick fur, streamlined bodies, or special roots help organisms survive in their specific habitats.
Biodiversity provides stability to ecosystems and needs to be conserved through responsible human actions.

chapters.title: Mindful Eating: A Path to a Healthy Body
topics: Different types of food we eat (cereals, pulses, fruits, vegetables, milk, fats)
Nutrients: carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, water, roughage
Balanced diet and its importance for growth and health
Health problems due to deficiency and excess of nutrients
Food hygiene, safe storage, and avoiding food wastage

notes.summary: This chapter relates daily food habits to nutrients and health, highlighting balanced diet, deficiencies, and the idea of eating mindfully.
key_points: Different foods provide different nutrients, so variety in meals is necessary for good health.
A balanced diet contains proper amounts of all nutrients, water, and roughage according to age and activity level.
Deficiency of nutrients can cause diseases like anemia or weak bones, while overeating junk food may lead to obesity.
Mindful eating means choosing nutritious food, eating at regular times, and avoiding overeating and too much processed food.
Clean cooking, safe storage, and proper hand‑washing help prevent food‑borne diseases.

chapters.title: Exploring Magnets
topics: Natural and artificial magnets
Magnetic and non‑magnetic materials
Poles of a magnet and their interactions
Finding directions using magnets
Uses of magnets in everyday life and safety with magnets

notes.summary: The chapter introduces magnets, their poles, and the idea of magnetic and non‑magnetic materials with simple hands‑on activities.
key_points: Magnets attract objects made of iron, nickel, or cobalt but do not attract materials like wood or plastic.
Every magnet has two poles, and like poles repel while unlike poles attract each other.
A freely suspended bar magnet comes to rest roughly in the north–south direction, which helps in finding directions.
Magnets are used in toys, doors, speakers, and many devices, so they should be stored properly to avoid damage.

chapters.title: Measurement of Length and Motion
topics: Need for standard units of measurement
SI unit of length and commonly used units (mm, cm, m, km)
Correct way of using a scale and avoiding errors
Types of motion: rectilinear, circular, periodic
Examples of motion from daily life (vehicles, clock, swing)

notes.summary: This chapter discusses measuring length accurately and recognizes different types of motion in the surroundings.
key_points: Standard units avoid confusion when comparing measurements between people and places.
The metre is the SI unit of length, and rulers or measuring tapes are used carefully to avoid parallax errors.
Rectilinear motion is along a straight line, circular motion around a fixed point, and periodic motion repeats after equal intervals.
Everyday objects like buses, fans, and pendulums show different kinds of motion that can be observed and described.

chapters.title: Materials Around Us
topics: Objects and materials in the surroundings
Grouping materials based on properties like appearance and hardness
Soluble and insoluble substances in water
Transparency: opaque, transparent, and translucent materials
Choosing suitable materials for different uses

notes.summary: This chapter helps students observe and group materials based on properties like luster, hardness, solubility, and transparency.
key_points: Things around us are made of different materials such as wood, metal, plastic, glass, and cotton.
Materials can be grouped using properties like shiny or dull, hard or soft, and heavy or light.
Some substances dissolve in water and are called soluble, while others do not dissolve and are called insoluble.
Transparent materials allow light to pass completely, translucent allow some light, and opaque do not allow light.
The choice of material for any object depends on the properties required for that use.

chapters.title: Temperature and its Measurement
topics: Hot and cold objects: feeling vs measurement
Thermometers and their basic parts
Units of temperature (degree Celsius)
Reading a thermometer correctly and precautions
Everyday examples of temperature (fever, weather, boiling water)

notes.summary: The chapter introduces temperature as a measurable quantity and explains how thermometers are used in daily life.
key_points: Our sense of hot and cold is not always reliable, so temperature is measured using instruments.
A thermometer has a glass tube and a liquid column with a scale marked in degree Celsius.
Clinical thermometers measure body temperature, while laboratory and room thermometers are used for other purposes.
Thermometers must be handled carefully and read at eye level to avoid wrong readings.

chapters.title: A Journey through States of Water
topics: Three states of water: solid, liquid, gas
Melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation
Factors affecting evaporation (surface area, wind, temperature)
Water cycle in nature
Importance of conserving water

notes.summary: This chapter explains how water changes its state and moves through the environment in the water cycle.
key_points: Water exists as ice, liquid water, and water vapour depending on temperature and conditions.
Heating and cooling cause changes of state such as melting, freezing, evaporation, and condensation.
Evaporation is faster when the surface area is large, the air is dry, or the temperature and wind speed are higher.
The water cycle involves evaporation, condensation, and precipitation, which continuously recycle water on Earth.
Saving water in homes, schools, and farms is essential because usable freshwater is limited.

chapters.title: Methods of Separation in Everyday Life
topics: Need for separating mixtures in daily life
Handpicking, winnowing, sieving
Sedimentation, decantation, filtration
Evaporation and condensation for separation
Applications like cleaning rice, purifying water, making common salt

notes.summary: The chapter links common household tasks to scientific methods of separating components of mixtures.
key_points: Mixtures are separated to remove harmful or unwanted substances and to obtain useful components.
Handpicking, winnowing, and sieving are used for solid–solid separation when particles differ in size or weight.
Sedimentation, decantation, and filtration help separate an insoluble solid from a liquid.
Evaporation is used to recover a solid dissolved in a liquid, such as common salt from seawater.
Different methods may be combined to achieve effective separation in real‑life situations.

chapters.title: Living Creatures: Exploring their Characteristics
topics: Basic characteristics of living organisms
Breathing and respiration in different organisms
Movement in plants and animals
Response to stimuli, growth, reproduction
Habitats and adaptations (link back to diversity chapter)

notes.summary: This chapter revisits what makes an organism living and studies life processes through simple examples.
key_points: Living beings show movement, need food, respire, excrete, grow, reproduce, and respond to changes around them.
Different animals breathe through lungs, gills, or moist skin, while plants exchange gases through stomata.
Plants also show slow movements such as bending towards light or closing of leaves on touch.
Habitats provide organisms with food, water, air, and shelter, and body features are adapted to these conditions.

chapters.title: Nature’s Treasures
topics: Air and its composition
Water as a resource and its forms
Soil, rocks, and minerals (basic ideas)
Energy from the Sun and its importance
Need for conservation of natural resources

notes.summary: The chapter highlights air, water, soil, rocks, minerals, and sunlight as valuable natural resources that support life.
key_points: Air is a mixture of gases like nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and water vapour, each with specific roles.
Water exists in rivers, lakes, groundwater, ice, and as vapour, and is essential for all living beings.
Soil forms from rocks over long periods and contains minerals, air, water, and organic matter.
The Sun is the main source of energy on Earth, driving the water cycle and supporting plant life through photosynthesis.
Careful use and protection of air, water, and soil are necessary for sustainable life on Earth.

chapters.title: Beyond Earth
topics: Earth as a planet in the solar system
The Moon and its features (phases, surface)
Other planets and basic idea of the solar system
Day and night due to rotation of Earth
Introduction to stars and constellations

notes.summary: This chapter introduces the solar system, Earth’s place in it, and simple ideas about the Moon, planets, and stars.
key_points: The solar system consists of the Sun, eight planets, their moons, and many smaller objects.
Earth supports life because of suitable air, water, and temperature conditions.
The Moon is Earth’s natural satellite and shows different phases due to changing positions of the Moon, Earth, and Sun.
Rotation of Earth on its axis causes day and night, while revolution around the Sun leads to change of seasons.
Stars are very distant suns, and some appear as patterns in the sky called constellations.
